Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: I sat at my desk, notes for the mentoring session spread out before me. My mentee was counting on me to guide her through the final steps before the big project deadline. I’d promised a clear, structured session—she needed my experience now more than ever. Just as I was about to start, my phone rang. It was a customer, one I recognized from countless calls. His voice was sharp, accusing. He demanded to know why our latest offer seemed misleading, pressing for details and explanations. As a telemarketer, I was expected to stay calm, address every objection, and keep him satisfied. But the clock was ticking, and my mentee was waiting, relying on me to help her succeed. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to my mentee and the obligation to resolve the customer’s concerns. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. I felt the tension coil in my chest, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed at the same time.
